title: The Covid-19 Origin Investigation
summary: Beijing spreads conspiracies while impeding WHO experts.. President Biden stopped America's withdrawal from the World Health Organization on his first day in office. The premise of his decision is that reforming international institutions from inside is more effective than leaving or withholding funds, and this theory will be tested quickly.

title: Henry Louis Aaron
summary: The home run king overcame racism and great pitchers.. Those wrists. Other hitters always talked about the strength in those wrists and forearms as they whipped a bat through the strike zone. What a sight as they knocked another pitch for a line-drive base hit or an arcing shot into the bleachers. Few-maybe no one else-could swing a baseball bat like Henry "Hank" Aaron, who died this week at age 86.

title: Biden's Fossil-Fuel Freeze
summary: Climate activists are now running federal oil and gas permitting.. Any doubt that the Biden Administration plans to slowly regulate fossil fuels out of existence vanished this week. First came the Keystone XL pipeline kill, but perhaps more significant is the 60-day freeze on new leases on federal lands and bureaucratic permitting. The pause could soon become a long-term ban.

title: Cuomo's Tax Ultimatum
summary: New York's Governor says bail him out or he'll punish New Yorkers.. Viewers of Andrew Cuomo's Emmy-award winning Covid-19 briefings may have noticed how the New York Governor has become increasingly excitable. In this week's budget show, he pointed an economic gun at New York and threatened to shoot if Washington doesn't fork over $15 billion.

title: Biden's Executive Orders Signal Collision Course With GOP
summary: President has taken more than two dozen executive actions, prompting cheers from Democrats and frustration from Republicans. WASHINGTON-President Biden signed an executive order Friday designed to swiftly deliver more relief to low-income families and unemployed workers, capping a series of actions taken in his first three days in office aimed at reversing Trump administration policies and enacting liberal priorities.

title: Companies Sell Stock at Record Pace to Start the Year
summary: U.S.-listed companies have conducted 80 follow-on stock offerings this year through Friday, raising $16.35 billion. Public companies have been taking advantage of a hot stock market by issuing shares at record pace in January.

title: Yes, the Senate Can Try Trump
summary: Impeachment for former officials was the norm at the time of the founding.. One of the first questions the Senate will face in Donald Trump's impeachment trial is whether the chamber has jurisdiction to hear a case against a former official. The correct answer is yes.

title: Trump's Worst Virus Failure
summary: He could have broken the norm that says don't deliver unwelcome news or treat voters like grown-ups.. My first surprise was that Donald Trump embraced the job after his 2016 win, not treating his election as an unwelcome accident, a publicity stunt gone awry, or a personal disaster facilitated by the mad interventions of James Comey.

title: The GOP Bid to Boot Gavin Newsom Could Backfire
summary: Republicans may feel good about their chances, but recalls often redound to the benefit of the recalled.. A push to recall California Gov. Gavin Newsom is gaining steam, and Republicans in the Golden State are feeling good about it. Public frustration with the state's pandemic response, combined with outrage at Mr. Newsom's inexplicable decision to attend a maskless dinner at the Michelin-starred French Laundry restaurant in November, has propelled a popular uprising against the first-term Democrat. The petitioners claim they have more than 1.1 million of the roughly 1.5 million valid signatures they must submit by March 17.

title: Yellen Approved for Treasury Chief by Senate Panel
summary: Nomination could go to Senate floor early next week after unanimous committee vote. WASHINGTON-A Senate panel voted Friday to approve Janet Yellen's nomination to be the next U.S. Treasury secretary, sending it to the full Senate, which could vote to confirm her early next week.

title: Short Bets Pummel Hot Hedge Fund Melvin Capital
summary: Fund that bet against GameStop, other stocks pays hefty price for shorting. Melvin Capital Management is down 15% just three weeks into 2021, thanks to a series of wrong-way bets that stocks including GameStop Corp. would slump.

title: United Looks to Require Workers to Get Covid-19 Vaccines
summary: United CEO calls on other companies to mandate vaccinations for their employees. United Airlines Holdings Inc. wants to require its workers to get Covid-19 vaccines, Chief Executive Scott Kirby told employees on Thursday, though he cautioned there are logistical hurdles to implementing such a mandate.

title: Biden Administration to Review Possible Sanctions Relief in Response to Covid-19
summary: The review could help clarify humanitarian assistance exceptions to U.S. sanctions during the pandemic, observers said. The Biden administration is expected to review existing economic sanctions for possible relief to help with the global response in combating the coronavirus pandemic.

title: Dow Drops but Notches Weekly Gain
summary: Markets pause after rallying for much of January. U.S. stocks wobbled Friday but managed to post weekly gains, lifted by shares that rallied on strong quarterly reports.

title: Demand Worries Drag on Oil Prices
summary: Output cuts and economic recovery in China were powering a rebound, but many traders are looking for increased consumption. Oil prices fell Friday, dragged lower by growing worries that the pandemic will spur greater restrictions on travel and economic activity.

title: Morgan Stanley CEO Got a Big Raise for 2020
summary: The bank's board awarded Mr. Gorman about $24 million in company stock and about $9 million in cash. Morgan Stanley paid Chief Executive James Gorman $33 million for his work in 2020, a 22% raise for a year in which the Wall Street firm generated record revenue, announced two multibillion-dollar acquisitions and avoided the worst of the pandemic-induced recession.

title: DOJ Weighs Amnesty for Academics to Disclose Foreign Funding
summary: Proposal comes as faculty members escalate opposition to criminal cases and the U.S. balances international academic collaboration with proper disclosure. Justice Department officials are weighing an amnesty program under which U.S. academics could disclose past foreign funding without fear of punishment for their disclosures, according to people familiar with the matter.

title: Investors Seek Out Riskiest Junk-Rated Bonds
summary: The prospect of a return to economic normalcy is powering a recovery in the lowest-rated junk debt. Investors' rush into the lowest-rated junk debt has driven yields to record lows, reflecting Wall Street's thirst for fixed-income returns and increasing confidence that even struggling businesses can survive the pandemic.

title: U.S. Covid-19 Cases, Hospitalizations Appear to Ease After Fall Surge
summary: The seven-day average of new cases has been incrementally declining, and hospitalizations show signs of improvement. Over a year since the first Covid-19 case was reported in the U.S., the country is struggling with the spread of the virus, the sluggish rollout of vaccines and a rising death toll.

title: United Wholesale Mortgage Goes Public in Biggest SPAC Deal Ever
summary: Merger with blank-check company takes mortgage lender public at valuation of $16 billion. United Wholesale Mortgage made its public trading debut Friday, the largest-ever listing through a special-purpose-acquisition company.

title: Labor Groups Push Biden Administration on Union-Friendly Priorities
summary: Efforts will likely face pushback from business community as union membership continues to decline. WASHINGTON-Labor unions are urging President Biden to move quickly to fulfill his campaign promise to champion organized labor and workers' rights, including by pushing for legislation to bolster unionizing efforts.

title: IBM Shares Are an Anomaly in a Hot Tech Sector
summary: Once the biggest U.S. company, IBM has struggled with its turnaround. International Business Machines Corp.'s stock is falling. Again.

title: Texas Files Suit Over Biden's Deportation Pause
summary: State attorney general says moratorium violates agreement signed with Trump administration on immigration policy changes. WASHINGTON-Texas sued the Biden administration in federal court over its decision to pause most deportations for 100 days, taking the lead in what is likely to be a series of conflicts between the new administration and states that struck agreements with the Trump administration on immigration policy.

title: Military Intelligence Agency Monitored U.S. Cellphone Movements Without Warrant
summary: DIA says it buys commercially available geolocation data and has used it five times in recent years for authorized investigations. WASHINGTON-In a new document made public Friday, the nation's top military intelligence agency acknowledged monitoring the location of U.S.-based mobile devices without a warrant through location data drawn from ordinary smartphone apps.

title: Biden Orders Analysis of 'Domestic Violent Extremism' Following Capitol Riot
summary: President directs national-security team to develop tools to assess and counter threat. WASHINGTON-President Biden has directed the intelligence community to assess the threat of domestic extremism and develop ways to identify and counter networks that promote it, the White House said Friday.

title: U.S. Home Sales Reach Highest Level in 14 Years
summary: Ultralow interest rates and remote work during the coronavirus pandemic spurred demand. U.S. home sales in 2020 surged to their highest level in 14 years, fueled by ultralow interest rates and a pandemic that sent buyers scrambling for more spacious homes to accommodate remote work.

title: Wardrobe Changes (Saturday Crossword, January 23)
Curly Quote (Saturday Variety Puzzle, January 23)
DoorDash Is Going to the Super Bowl. So Are Other Brands That Did Well During the Pandemic.
summary: The delivery company wants to keep the momentum going after a strong year. DoorDash Inc. will advertise in the Super Bowl for the first time next month as it kicks off a larger marketing campaign promoting its options beyond food delivery. The move follows a year in which the company went public and experienced growth during the lockdowns of the coronavirus pandemic.

title: AstraZeneca Warns of Covid-19 Vaccine Shortfall in Europe
summary: Pfizer had issued a similar warning, as EU officials face scrutiny over vaccine rollout. LONDON- AstraZeneca PLC told European Union officials that fewer doses of its Covid-19 vaccine will be ready for the bloc's planned rollout in early February, blaming an unspecified manufacturing issue.

title: Comcast's NBCUniversal to Shut Down Sports Cable Channel NBCSN
summary: National Hockey League, Nascar programming will move to network USA. NBCUniversal is shutting down its sports cable channel NBCSN at the end of the year and migrating much of its programming to its sister general entertainment network USA, the company said.

title: Sanskrit Epics Animated in Stone
summary: Ornately-carved pillars and friezes from a 16th-century South Indian temple bring the stories of the Ramayana and Mahabharata to life.. Stepping into the South Asian galleries of the Philadelphia Museum of Art (which reopened on Jan. 8 after being closed due to Covid-19), we walk between two large figures that artists in South India carved around 1560. They don't immediately register as pillars, so prominently do the sculptures protrude. One portrays a handsome young man sitting under a tree looking rather pleased with himself. He is Rama, god and hero of the Ramayana epic, flanked by his wife, Sita, and the ever-loyal monkey king, Hanuman, carved in relief on either side of the monolithic pillar. Opposite him stands a bearded man with the haunches of a beast, leaning forward, club raised to do battle. Yet this "man-beast," or Purushamirukam, feels more theatrical than menacing with his mound of neatly coiffed hair, delicately arched eyebrows, and loads of jewelry. He isn't about to attack; he's enacting a story.

title: Keystone Pipeline Cancellation Raises Pressure on Canadian Producers
summary: Oil-and-gas companies seek new routes to market for Canada's top export. TORONTO-President Biden's revocation of a permit for TC Energy Corp.'s Keystone XL pipeline is raising pressure on Canada's energy industry to seek new markets for oil and gas, its top export.

title: 'The Bachelor' Creator Mike Fleiss Asks $34.5 Million for Oceanfront Kauai Home
summary: The television producer is listing the two-acre property for more than double what he paid Julia Roberts for it in 2016. Mike Fleiss, creator of the hit ABC-TV dating shows "The Bachelor" and "The Bachelorette," is asking $34.5 million for a Kauai property-or more than twice what he paid actress Julia Roberts for it five years ago.

title: A Plantation-Style Home on Hanalei Bay
summary: Once owned by actress Julia Roberts, the relatively modest four-bedroom dates back more than a century. We are delighted that you'd like to resume your subscription.

title: The Flying Dutchmen
summary: This complex creation from mixologist Tess Posthumus is the signature drink at her Amsterdam bar, Flying Dutchmen Cocktails. To explore and search through all our recipes, check out the new WSJ Recipes page.

title: Travel to Amsterdam Through Films, Music, Food and More
summary: Until you can jet off to The Netherlands worry-free, we've devised ways to immerse yourself in its capital from afar. In the new "Wish You Were There" series, we offer a virtual visit to a beloved destination by asking locals and insiders to recommend transportive films, books, music and podcasts, as well as a few quintessential drinks and dishes. Bon voyage!

title: 'Ghost Ship' Fire Defendant Pleads Guilty to Manslaughter Charges
summary: Derick Almena accused of maintaining an unsafe space that led to death of 36 in 2016 blaze. More than four years after an Oakland, Calif., warehouse fire killed 36 people, the man who leased and controlled the space pleaded guilty Friday to 36 counts of involuntary manslaughter.

title: How to Celebrate Mardi Gras During Covid: Turn Your House Into a Parade Float
summary: Resume Subscription. NEW ORLEANS-When the mayor of New Orleans announced back in November that the city was canceling this year's Mardi Gras parades, Megan Joy Boudreaux decided she would transform her house into a float and chuck necklaces at her neighbors from her front porch instead.

title: ECB Considers Halting Private Calls to Banks
summary: The practice had raised eyebrows among financiers and central-bank officials because it risked privileging large investors with sensitive information. FRANKFURT-The European Central Bank is considering terminating an unusual communications policy whereby its chief economist placed private calls to banks and investors shortly after policy meetings, a practice that had raised eyebrows among financiers and central-bank officials.

title: Let Them Learn
summary: A governor wants to let kids back in school. Meanwhile a president lets bureaucrats play.. Americans observing recent Joe Biden speeches may be relieved to know that not all politicians think parents should have to wait another 100 days before their kids are allowed back into classrooms. Understanding that few teachers and even fewer students are at high risk from Covid-19, Iowa's governor is determined to let kids learn in school. The encouraging reform idea is to let parents decide both where their children attend school and whether they want in-person instruction.

title: Baseball Legend Hank Aaron Dies at 86
summary: The slugger's 755 career home runs stood as a record for more than three decades.. We are delighted that you'd like to resume your subscription.

title: IBM Can't Spin Its Way Out of Trouble
summary: Disappointing results bring stock back to where it was before the company announced a spin-off meant to boost growth prospects. IBM is learning fast that even ambitious weight loss plans don't always solve everything.

title: Amazon Seeks to Postpone Alabama Unionization Vote
summary: Tech company pushes for in-person union ballot in place of mail-in option allowed due to pandemic. Amazon.com Inc. is seeking to postpone a unionization vote at a warehouse in Alabama and is asking federal labor authorities to reconsider a decision to allow mail-in voting due to the pandemic.

title: What That Pandemic Puppy Will Cost You
summary: Many people didn't think about expenses when adopting a dog. Here's what you can expect to spend-and how you can keep the bills down.. For all the love and companionship that dogs provide-think of all the locked-down people who have adopted them during the pandemic-they all come with a less-adorable characteristic: bills.

title: American Women in Florence
summary: Collector Christian Levett has filled his Italian palazzo with a world-class assembly of works by female Abstract Expressionists.. Spread over two floors of a palazzo beside the River Arno in Florence, amid the treasures of the Italian Renaissance, is perhaps the world's largest private collection of art by modern female abstractionists.

title: Every Warren Buffett Needs a Charlie Munger
summary: Online trading buddies can lift you up when you're feeling down. But real-world friends tell you when you're wrong.. As anyone who's ever raised-or been-a teenager knows, happy outcomes are rare when groups of people egg each other on in a risky activity.

title: Trump and the Failure of the Expert Class
summary: They were right about his character, but his defects were obvious to almost everyone. They were wrong about virtually all else.. The Trump years had something for almost everyone. Progressives had the satisfaction of righteousness and a justification for daily outrage. What they didn't have were policy victories, although they might have had a few if they could have refrained, even for a few days, from treating the president as illegitimate. For conservatives, the case was exactly reversed: They had some major policy wins, but at the cost of frequent embarrassment and dismay at the president's offensive behavior and self-defeating logorrhea.

title: Joe Biden's First Day Began the End of Girls' Sports
summary: An executive order rigs competition by requiring that biological boys be allowed to compete against girls.. Amid Inauguration Day talk of shattered glass ceilings, on Wednesday President Biden delivered a body blow to the rights of women and girls: the Executive Order on Preventing and Combating Discrimination on the Basis of Gender Identity or Sexual Orientation. On day one, Mr. Biden placed all girls' sports and women's safe spaces in the crosshairs of the administrative state.

title: Has the Left Hijacked King's Loving Vision?
summary: Much of Martin Luther King Jr.'s work has apparently been forgotten.. Robert L. Woodson Sr. and Joshua Mitchell fail to present a convincing case that the left has hijacked the struggle for civil rights ("How the Left Hijacked Civil Rights," op-ed, Jan. 16). They claim many black leaders reject the country's founding principles. Not so. What many modern black leaders do is shine a bright light on the gross hypocrisy of declaring "all men are created equal" while tolerating slavery, Jim Crow, mass incarceration, lynchings and general discrimination both social and governmental throughout our history.

title: What Does Trumpism Mean for the Future?
summary: Desperate evangelicals and social conservatives held their noses but voted for Donald Trump because he promised to make America great again by restoring traditional moral and Christian values.. Regarding Gerald F. Seib's "Where Trump Came From-And Where Trumpism Is Going" (Review, Jan. 16): Trumpism isn't limited to supporters of Donald J. Trump. It is a style of political and social behavior practiced by a wide swath of those on the left and right, which employs personal invective and emphasizes hatred of "the other."

title: Hartford Has a Lot to Offer, Now and Ahead
summary: The Brookings Institution named Hartford one of 19 global "Knowledge Capitals" for its talented workforce, elite research universities and entrepreneurial spirit.. I am CEO of one of the largest private-sector employers in Hartford, Conn., and want to comment on Bob Stefanowski's "What Isn't the Matter With Hartford?" (Cross Country, Jan. 2). Hartford remains the hub of Travelers' business operations for reasons that go well beyond our 157-year history in the city.

title: A New Era for an Old Term of Honor as the U.S. Gets a Second 'Gentleman'
summary: A medieval English title becomes a job description for Doug Emhoff, the husband of Vice President Kamala Harris.. While Kamala Harrishas made history by becoming the first female, first Black and first South Asian vice president, her husband Doug Emhoff is blazing his own trail as the nation's first "Second Gentleman." The Biden administration's White House website prominently emblazons Mr. Emhoff's page with the title "Second Gentleman," and his official Twitter handle is likewise @SecondGentleman.

title: Are Gyms Dead? Why Home Workouts Are Here to Stay
summary: With one in four gyms projected to close last year due to the pandemic, Americans began spending big on Pelotons and other digitally connected home-workout equipment. Now some say we'll never go back.. WITH THE ONSET of Covid-19, gyms across the country closed their doors. Many of us who habitually hit a spin class or gritted our teeth through circuit training were newly stranded at home, confronting the seeming inevitability of flabbiness. Where were our walls of mirrors? Our post-workout showers that let us hand-pump hair conditioner so liberally? As our scrunchies lay dormant, we even grew wistful for the awkwardness of locker rooms.

title: For Oil Servicers, Adversity Spells Opportunity
summary: Oil-field services companies show signs of improvement; sentiment-driven selloff could be opportunity to pick up shares on the cheap. Discipline has been the mantra of American energy companies for a while. Judging from oil-field services companies' results this week, they are walking the walk, not just talking the talk.

title: Senate Confirms Lloyd Austin as Defense Secretary
summary: Retired Army general becomes first Black chief of the Defense Department. The U.S. Senate on Friday confirmed Lloyd Austin, a retired Army general who most recently led all U.S. military operations in the Middle East, as President Biden's defense secretary, making him the first Black secretary ever to run the department.

title: Anger at China's Covid-19 Response Smolders in Wuhan
summary: Resume Subscription. WUHAN, China-In the original center of the coronavirus pandemic, there is a monument to China's fight against Covid-19.

title: Biden Aims to Boost Vaccine Distribution by Using a 1950s Law
summary: Defense Production Act won't have an immediate meaningful impact on vaccine production but could increase syringe supplies. President Biden's plan to use a Cold War-era law to boost the Covid-19 vaccination effort isn't likely to expand production significantly in the near term, but it could jump-start vaccinations by increasing other supplies such as syringes, vaccine manufacturers and experts say.

title: Google Closes Loon, Its Plan to Use Balloons for Web Access
summary: Project that sought to provide internet access in hard-to-reach regions winds down over cost concerns. Google's parent company is winding down a project that used highflying balloons to provide internet access in hard-to-reach regions of the world, as it retreats from some of the moonshot projects championed by its founders.

title: Colorful Homes Are Taking Center Stage Thanks to Instagram
summary: Resume Subscription. Interior designer Noz Nozawa has made a career out of color. So when the three-unit condominium where she lives in San Francisco needed a fresh coat of paint, she wasn't going to let it remain a "mucky, non-color."

title: The New Face of Charitable Giving During the Pandemic
summary: Donors gave more money, and thought of new ways to donate. The pandemic has inspired a wave of charitable giving-some through traditional methods, some by more innovative means.

title: James Taylor Looks Back on His Early Years
summary: At 72, the music legend who wrote 'Fire and Rain' and 'Something in the Way She Moves' reflects fondly on 'the arrogance of youth'. It might seem unusual, even presumptuous, for a 72-year-old man to write a memoir covering just the first 21 years of his life, as James Taylor did last year with "Break Shot," published as an Audible Original audiobook. But Mr. Taylor's first two decades were extraordinary. He had already lived a privileged but tormented childhood, seen his New York rock 'n' roll dreams collapse, spent time in a mental institution, been addicted to heroin, recorded with the Beatles, lived in both swinging London and Los Angeles' Laurel Canyon at its creative peak, and cut a landmark second album, "Sweet Baby James," that included the classic "Fire and Rain."

title: Hank Aaron, Longtime Home Run King and Civil Rights Icon, Dies at 86
summary: The slugger faced death threats as he approached Babe Ruth's home run record in 1974. His 755 career home runs stood as a record for more than three decades.. Hank Aaron, one of most prodigious sluggers in Major League Baseball history and a reluctant civil rights icon whose 755 home runs stood as the all-time record for more than three decades, has died. He was 86.

title: Electric-Vehicle Surge Sends Cobalt Prices Soaring
summary: China controls big chunk of market for key metal in car batteries that is mined largely in Africa. A 20% rise in the price of cobalt since the beginning of this year shows how the rush to build more electric vehicles is stressing global supply chains.

title: Ford F-150 PowerBoost: Enough AC Outlets to Fuel a Monster Tailgating Party
summary: This hybrid truck features a Pro Power Onboard system that feeds a panel of outlets in the cargo bed-and it's amazing, writes Dan Neil. I DON'T HAVE to keep pecking away at this keyboard, you know. I have practical skills. I could get my contractor's license and build houses, like my brother. I always wanted to farm oysters down at the coast and sell them on the side of the road at ridiculous prices. With a little practice, I'm sure I could be the worst welder in town.

title: U.S. Business Activity Gains at Start of Year
summary: Purchasing-managers surveys show American economy gaining momentum, risk of recession growing in Europe. The U.S. economy picked up momentum at the start of the year, while Europe showed a growing risk of a second recession amid tougher restrictions to contain coronavirus infections, surveys of purchasing managers showed.

title: Covid-19 Tests Are Still Hard to Get in Many Communities
summary: Nearly 20% of U.S. counties have no test site, many in low-income rural and urban areas. Access to Covid-19 testing remains limited in many lower-income areas of the U.S. nearly a year into the pandemic, complicating efforts to contain the spreading virus.

title: China Played Its Hand Well in 2020. Will It Keep Winning?
summary: While American democracy struggled to cope with the pandemic, economic crisis and political unrest, Chinese authoritarianism could point to notable successes-and rising international clout.. In late 2019, a group of international public health experts set out to assess pandemic preparedness around the world. Using criteria such as early virus detection, speed of response and adherence to international health norms, they ranked the U.S. first, China a distant fifty-first.

title: 'The Good American' Review: Field Work for Humanity
summary: Robert Gersony's job was investigating human misery. Not everyone welcomed the truth.. As a government official, I twice had the good fortune to meet Robert Paul Gersony, whose adventurous and consequential life is the subject of a remarkable biography by Robert Kaplan, his friend of 30 years. Mr. Kaplan, the well-known author of a dozen books about foreign affairs, calls "The Good American" his "most important and ambitious work," an inspiring story of "America in the wider world."

title: 'Sybille Bedford' Review: The Call of the Page
summary: Throughout Bedford's books, the depth of human tragedy lies just beneath a comedy of manners.. 'The nightmare fable of our time is a true story," Sybille Bedford once declared. She would know. Born in Berlin before World War I and living for almost a century in France, Italy, England and, briefly, the United States, she chronicled that nightmare fable in a series of extraordinary and often uncategorizable books: four novels, a two-volume biography of Aldous Huxley, a comparative study of the legal systems in five countries, a book about Mexico and one on the trial of the English doctor whose wealthy patients (mainly female) kept mysteriously dying, though not before writing him into their wills. She also covered the trial of Jack Ruby, the obscenity case against "Lady Chatterley's Lover," and the 14-month long prosecution of the guards at Auschwitz-when, that is, not writing about food or wine.

title: 'The Ratline' Review: A Father's Dark Path
summary: Researching the life of a high-ranking Nazi, the author comes to know the man's son-ﬁrst amiably, then contentiously.. In 'East West Street' (2016), the British human-rights lawyer Philippe Sands discovered the story of a man who had maintained a lifelong silence about his own story: his maternal grandfather, a Jew who in 1939 was forced to flee to Paris, where he survived the German occupation with false papers. The book interweaves this narrative with an account of the two legal minds who introduced the terms "genocide" and "crimes against humanity" into international law. Each of the three men had come from Galicia, a region at the eastern edge of the Habsburg Empire; each suffered grievous losses of family members at the hands of the province's Nazi rulers. Less than 3% of Galicia's prewar Jewish population survived.

title: Fiction: 'The Copenhagen Trilogy' Review
summary: A Danish writer's autobiographical fiction immerses the reader in her troubled experience, moment by moment.. The calculus of literary revival is complicated by so many variables that no one can ever quite say why some books strike a chord and some don't. Consider "The Copenhagen Trilogy" (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, 370 pages, $30) by Tove Ditlevsen, originally published between 1967 and 1971. Ditlevsen (1917-1976) was a celebrated postwar Danish writer whose profuse output continued throughout her troubled life until her death from an overdose of sleeping pills when she was 58. In 1985 Tiina Nunnally translated and published the first two volumes of the autobiographical trilogy ("Childhood" and "Youth") in a single book titled "Early Spring," which disappeared with hardly a ripple. But last year Ms. Nunnally's versions were joined with Michael Favala Goldman's translation of the third volume, "Dependency," and published in the U.K. to extravagant critical acclaim. The praise has wafted into the U.S., where the work now arrives in a pricy hardcover from the country's most prestigious publishing house-50-year-old Danish esoterica refashioned into one of the most anticipated releases of the season.

title: 'The Crown in Crisis' Review: The Year of Three Kings
summary: As Edward VIII made his plans for marriage clear, even his bride-to-be worried the price would be too high.. Alexander Larman opens "The Crown in Crisis" with a gleeful quote about the abdication of Edward VIII from Evelyn Waugh's diary: "There can seldom have been an event that has caused so much general delight and so little pain." Even now, over 80 years later, the saga of the king and the much reviled, twice-divorced American socialite Wallis Simpson continues to entertain. The public has never tired of hearing about anything that concerns the British monarchy-but this scandal has proven a particularly enduring hit. In his fresh chronicle of the dramatic events leading up to the abdication, Mr. Larman, a historian and journalist, has unearthed newly released archives, unpublished letters and interviews with people who knew the couple.

title: 'The Good Girls' Review: Village of Fear
summary: The tragedy of 'Padma Lalli' points at the danger many Indian women face, right at home.. On the morning of May 28, 2014, two girls-cousins age 16 and 14-were found hanging from a mango tree in a remote village six hours southeast of New Delhi. They'd left their scruffy family compound the night before, telling the adults they needed to relieve themselves in the fields nearby. Like every other dwelling in this part of Uttar Pradesh-India's most populous state and among its most impoverished-their home had no toilet.

title: Children's Books:'The Great Gatsby: A Graphic Novel Adaptation' Review
summary: Picturing the Jazz Age with the classic story of American self-invention.. Something's always lost when a book gets translated into a film, stage show or graphic novel. But something's often gained, too, as is manifestly the case with K. Woodman-Maynard's illustrated adaptation of "The Great Gatsby" (Candlewick, 232 pages, $24.99). The book is rendered in luxe colors of rose, gold, amethyst and aquamarine, making us feel as though we're watching the events of F. Scott Fitzgerald's 1925 novel through gems held up to the light.

title: 'Slough House' Review: Spies Out to Pasture
summary: Jackson Lamb and the other 'slow horses' are expendable assets in a cynical covert struggle.. Like Patrick O'Brian, who ultimately found his sweet spot in the Royal Navy of the early 19th century, Mick Herron eventually found his in Britain's domestic intelligence service of the present day. Out of a wickedly imagined version of MI5, he has spun works of diabolical plotting and high-spirited cynicism, their pages filled with sardonic wit, their characters approaching the surreal. Up until a little over 10 years ago, Mr. Herron had produced a four-novel sequence starring a female PI, a stand-alone spy novel involving MI6 and a collection of short stories. Though entertaining enough, the books lack the animating genius of the seven novels and three novellas that make up his current series. Inevitably, and we hope with an appropriate degree of mordant humor, the books are now the basis for a television series, coming from Apple, starring Gary Oldman, Olivia Cooke, Kristin Scott Thomas, Jonathan Pryce and Jack Lowden.

title: 'The Last Shah' Review: A Purely Domestic Conspiracy
summary: No single force ousted Iranian leader Mohammad Mossadeq, but in the end only one man stood to benefit.. Weaving conspiracy theories is a kind of art form in parts of the Middle East, and the Iranians are the undisputed masters. So pervasive is conspiracy theorizing in Iran that the "Encyclopaedia Iranica," a scholarly guide to the country's history and culture, contains a long and learned article documenting the many influential writers who attribute "the course of Persian history and politics to the machinations of hostile foreign powers and secret organizations."

title: Benjamin de Rothschild Carried On a Banking Tradition in Europe
summary: Financier, who has died at age 57, preferred outdoor adventures but saw his stewardship of the family empire as inevitable. Benjamin de Rothschild's preferred pursuits included flashing down snowy slopes on his skies, and racing cars, motorcycles and sailboats. "There isn't a bone in my body that I haven't broken," he once boasted.

title: Egypt Battles Over Memories of the Arab Spring
summary: Despite the current regime's efforts to suppress dissent, millions of Egyptians still find inspiration in the Tahrir Square uprising that toppled the country's autocratic ruler 10 years ago. Egypt's 2011 revolution changed Sameh Abdelbadie's life. The uprising that overthrew President Hosni Mubarak, the country's longtime autocrat, inspired the 18-year-old to paint revolution-themed murals and organize protests at Cairo University.

title: Five Best: Philip Terzian on Memoirs by Writers
summary: Selected by the author of 'Architects of Power: Roosevelt, Eisenhower, and the American Century.'. By Edmund Wilson (5 vols., 1975-93)

title: At the Biden-Harris Inauguration, Emerging Fashion Designers Win Big
summary: Wednesday's ceremony instantly boosted lesser-known designers like Batsheva Hay who dressed Ella Emhoff and Sergio Hudson who created Michelle Obama's look, spiking sales and social-media buzz. Here, a guide to these rising stars.. THE FASHION at Wednesday's inauguration put American designers front and center, including several emerging American designers-who particularly stand to benefit from the attention. President Joe Biden's Ralph Lauren suit got respectful reviews, but outfits designed by Sergio Hudson and Alexandra O'Neill, names far less widely known, were singled out for special praise. This level of exposure can make a huge difference, said Ikram Goldman, the Chicago retailer who gravitated to the work of many undersung designers when helping style Michelle Obama during the Obama administration. "These are unknown designers that are being worn by people in the limelight," she pointed out, "and that combination...makes an impact on a lot of levels."

title: Auto Investors Are Doing the Charleston
summary: Wall Street has a 1920s mood and one of the same obsessions-car companies. Is it time to bring back the Flappers?

title: IBM, Intel, Adamis, GameStop: What to Watch When the Stock Market Opens Today
summary: Markets appeared to be pausing after rallying for much of January. Here's what we're watching ahead of Friday's opening bell.

title: WHO Caught Between China and West on Frozen-Food Coronavirus Transmission
summary: Chinese officials have blamed frozen-food imports as one reason for the country's new Covid-19 infections. The World Health Organization is caught in an escalating dispute over whether the coronavirus is spreading on frozen-food packaging, as China steps up efforts to promote the theory and the U.S., European Union and others lobby against extra checks on their goods.

title: How Long It Will Take to Get Vaccines to Most Americans
summary: At current pace, it could take into 2022, although Biden administration's efforts and vaccines in development may speed pace. The U.S. has been administering doses of the Covid-19 vaccine since mid-December. As health departments across the country get their vaccination efforts up and running-some more successfully than others-President Biden's administration is hoping to quicken the process.

title: Surging Grain Prices Fuel Surprise Farm Recovery
summary: Higher commodity prices are benefiting grain farmers but could lead to higher prices at the grocery store. A crop glut that battered American farmers is subsiding, fueling an unexpected recovery in the U.S. Farm Belt following a yearslong agricultural recession.

title: Vision Boarding in a Year of Uncertainty
summary: Collaging imagery into a vision board of goals and desires has been a popular "manifesting" technique since the mid-2000s. But in a year when we have little idea if we'll be able to travel, have weddings or get promoted, are vision boards just depressing?. I conjured my first vision board at the end of 2019. My friend Jen and I bought piles of magazines and stocked up on art supplies like poster board, glitter and glue. After we finished assembling our boards, I hung mine above a mirror across from my bed, so that I would see it every day when I woke up. One March day shortly after starting to work from home in New York last year, it fell down and hit me on the head. As far as symbolism for 2020 goes, it felt a little like overkill.

title: The NBA's Pandemic Request: Yes to Dunks, No to Hugs
summary: Basketball, soccer and other sports are trying to limit unnecessary contact. It's not so easy.. Today, Thursday, Jan. 21, is National Hugging Day-really, this is an actual thing, you can google it. And if this sounds like an awkward, inadvisable holiday amid socially distant times, it's especially so in sports, where a hug clampdown has commenced.

title: London's Financial Center to Remove Statues Linked to Slavery
summary: Decision comes as Black Lives Matter movement sparks debate over U.K.'s colonial past. London's historic financial district has voted to remove statues of two 18th- century merchants who profited from slavery after the Black Lives Matter movement prompted growing scrutiny of the U.K.'s role in the trans-Atlantic slave trade.

title: Studies of South African Virus Strain Raise Immunity Concerns
summary: Findings suggest vaccine makers may need to update shots as virus evolves, as with flu vaccinations. JOHANNESBURG-Three new laboratory studies are raising concerns that the immune response triggered by a Covid-19 infection or vaccination may be less effective at protecting against the new strain of the coronavirus that first emerged in South Africa.

title: Wave of Women in Congress Puts Men in Top Supporting Roles
summary: Charlie Capito, husband of West Virginia senator, becomes first man to lead Congressional Club for spouses. WASHINGTON-Another glass ceiling of sorts was shattered in Washington this week-beyond the first female vice president.

title: Tom Brady's Chance to Work From Home-at the Super Bowl
summary: The Tampa Bay Buccaneers are one win away from becoming the first team to play the Super Bowl at its home stadium. The chances that it never happened before? Really low.. Tom Brady has been to nine Super Bowls, won six and is one game from something that's never been done in NFL history: playing a Super Bowl at home.

title: Hong Kong's Hang Seng Index Battles Midlife Crisis: Boring Stocks and Blacklists
summary: The index and its mix of stocks will be getting a makeover. The Hang Seng Index, the main barometer of Hong Kong's $6 trillion stock market, has fallen behind the times and now faces an uncertain future.

title: General Partners Add Show-Biz Touches to Virtual Meetings
summary: Private-equity leaders take on newscaster roles as they work, sometimes awkwardly, to mitigate Zoom fatigue during investor meetings. Platinum Equity partner Mark Barnhill took some time to adjust during the firm's first online annual investor meeting in November.

title: Stefon Diggs Made a Miracle. Then He Made Josh Allen a Star.
summary: The Buffalo Bills needed to stretch the field, so they paid a huge price for a receiver who excels at just that. Then they became a Super Bowl contender.. When Americans were first grappling with how a novel coronavirus would upend their lives last March, the Buffalo Bills made a bold move to boost their own uncertain future.

title: Dozens Face Criminal Complaints in Thailand, Accused of Insulting the King
summary: Most are protesters who have changed the country's political landscape in recent months.

title: Markets Are Convinced: The Fed Won't Come for the Punch Bowl
summary: The Treasury selloff is about inflation expectations, not higher 'real' yields. Investors may need to adjust their old playbooks.. Global investors have seized on the idea that the Federal Reserve will keep interest rates low as inflation rises. But they still need to fully figure out what this means for their portfolios.

title: Islamic State Claims Responsibility for Deadly Baghdad Bombings
summary: Dozens killed in twin explosions, which shatter a period of relative calm and highlight Iraq's challenges amid U.S. withdrawal. BAGHDAD-Twin suicide bombings ripped through a crowded marketplace in Baghdad on Thursday, killing at least 32 people and wounding at least 75 others in the first such attack in Iraq's capital in more than two years.

title: Biden Proposes Extending New START Arms Deal
summary: President vowed during campaign to extend the New START treaty, which is scheduled to lapse on Feb. 5. President Biden proposed Thursday that a centerpiece U.S.-Russia nuclear arms treaty be extended for five years, a decision that marks the first major foreign policy action of his administration as he seeks to confront national security challenges while grappling with the coronavirus pandemic and economic distress at home.

title: Paramount+ Marketing Push Will Rely Heavily on ViacomCBS Networks
summary: Media companies' new streaming services have one advantage over tech rivals such as Netflix: cross-promotion opportunities. ViacomCBS Inc. will begin a 13-week marketing campaign for its coming Paramount+ streaming service with advertising during the National Football League's AFC Championship game this Sunday, followed by ads during the Super Bowl, the Grammy Awards, the Masters and March Madness.

title: Why I'm Abstaining From Dry January
summary: Our wine columnist consults medical experts on the benefits that the comforting ritual of wine drinking can bring. I'VE SPENT THE past few weeks reading the social-media accounts of friends and acquaintances touting their wineless state during Dry January, aka Dryuary (or even, awkwardly, Drynuary). Some have been taking a few days off alcohol during the week; others are spending an entire month alcohol-free. I haven't joined them. My plan has been to drink wine in modest amounts with dinner every day in January, just as I do during the other eleven months of the year.

title: SPACs Rescued Wall Street From the Covid Doldrums
summary: Initial public offerings from so-called blank-check companies gave a boost to banks' stock-selling operations. In 2020, underwriters were the kings of Wall Street.

title: SPAC Demand to Draw VCs to Cleantech
summary: Interest in taking clean technology companies public surged after a decade when few such companies reached public markets. Clean technology startups have become a hot commodity on the public markets as special-purpose acquisition companies flush with cash hunt for targets.

title: Covid-19 Data Remain Mired in Inconsistencies
summary: A year after first U.S. case, testing is uneven, case counts are too low and death tallies are incomplete. When the daily demands of pandemic management subside, researchers will want to survey the damage wreaked by Covid-19 and assess how health-care systems and policy makers responded to the scourge.

title: Unusable Invitations, Soldiers in Hotel Rooms: Washington's Deflated Inaugural
summary: Capital region likely suffered major financial hit from crowdless inauguration. WASHINGTON'S INAUGURAL RESOURCES get repurposed for a crowd-free ceremony in a city on lockdown. The Government Printing Office produced thousands of tickets, invitations, programs-even parking passes. And rather than let them go to waste, they plan on distributing them after the fact as mementos. The materials will be doled out to individual congressional offices, like they would be for a typical inaugural.

title: Amid Housing Boom, Demand for Small Spaces Grows Too
summary: Tiny homes, rentable for about the price of a traditional apartment unit of the same size, are being built fast. The pandemic sent many Americans dreaming of more space and scurrying to find it. Sales of large homes are booming. So too are tiny ones.

title: American Eagle Outfitters CFO Seeks to Provide Investors With Additional Insights
summary: The clothing retailer plans to break out results for its namesake and Aerie brands separately. Clothing retailer American Eagle Outfitters Inc. will start breaking out results for its namesake and Aerie brands separately as its businesses are growing at different speeds and investors seek additional insights.

title: Defense Act Extends Anti-Money-Laundering Requirements to Antiquities Market
summary: A provision of the legislation also asks the Treasury Department to conduct a study on the facilitation of money laundering through the art market. The U.S. Treasury Department will propose new rules extending anti-money-laundering requirements to antiquities dealers, as part of recently passed defense-policy legislation.

title: Mexico Working on Alternative to Bill That Would Force Central Bank to Buy Dollars
summary: Controversy around the bill led the government to seek a way to help migrants change dollars while protecting the Bank of Mexico's autonomy. MEXICO CITY-The Mexican government is preparing a banking product to help migrant workers change their dollars as an alternative to a bill in Congress that would put the responsibility for excess foreign cash on the central bank, Mexico's top finance official said.

title: Amazon Needs Electric Vehicles, Too
summary: In the frothy EV sector, companies focused on parcel-delivery vans have a stronger business case than most. When you think of electric vehicles, you might think first of a Tesla. But a more financially rewarding use of the technology that is upending the automotive industry could be the vans that deliver your online shopping.

title: Purell Maker Bets Sanitizing Habits Outlast the Pandemic
summary: Gojo Industries adds second factory, expecting new hygiene habits will remain after Covid-19 crisis fades.

title: TikTok Rival's IPO Could Value It Near $100 Billion
summary: The coming IPO of Tencent-backed Kuaishou in Hong Kong could be one of the city's biggest. TikTok was undoubtedly the most talked about app in 2020, both for its viral popularity and the resulting political troubles. Its largest competitor in China hasn't received as much scrutiny abroad, but could still make a splash in the market.

title: Google Threatens Search Shutdown in Australia
summary: Fight is over a proposed law requiring tech giants to pay publishers for news. SYDNEY-Google threatened to shut down its search engine in Australia if a proposed law requiring tech giants to pay publishers for news isn't changed.

title: Pepper...and Salt
summary: Resume Subscription. We are delighted that you'd like to resume your subscription.

title: Inauguration Day Protests in Portland, Seattle Turned Violent
summary: More than a dozen arrested following demonstrations with anti-law-enforcement messaging. Police in Portland, Ore., and Seattle arrested more than a dozen people Wednesday after Inauguration Day protests led to the vandalizing of immigration offices and other buildings in both cities.

title: Chinese Telecom Carriers Ask NYSE to Make Another U-Turn on Delisting
summary: Companies say they operated in accordance with laws and regulations, and followed regulatory requirements of listing venues. China's big telecom carriers asked the New York Stock Exchange to rethink their planned delisting, the latest twist in a to-and-fro about whether they should be allowed to trade in U.S. markets.

title: Jack Ma Is Back, but Ant's Troubles Are Far From Over
summary: A tougher regulatory approach-and probably slower growth-now look inevitable. Chinese billionaire Jack Ma, once the richest man in the country, has resurfaced after being out of the public eye for months. But his real troubles-and those of his business empire-may be just beginning.

title: President Biden Will Keep Christopher Wray as FBI Director
summary: Decision provides stability atop agency as new administration confronts rising threat of domestic extremism after Capitol riot. WASHINGTON-President Biden will keep Christopher Wray in place as FBI director, the White House confirmed Thursday, providing stability atop the nation's premier law-enforcement agency as the new administration confronts the rising threat of domestic extremism after the deadly riot at the U.S. Capitol.

title: Biden Moves to Jump-Start Covid Fight With Slew of Orders
summary: Face masks are required in airports and certain public transportation, including many trains, ships, intercity buses and airplanes. WASHINGTON-President Biden signed 10 executive orders on his first full day in office to combat the coronavirus, seeking Thursday to jump-start the U.S. response to the pandemic while warning it will take "many months to get where we need to be."

title: Augmented Reality Used in Knee-Replacement Surgery in a U.S. First
summary: Data streamed through smart glasses allow for precise removal of bone and cartilage and accurate positioning of knee implants. A surgeon at the Hospital for Special Surgery in New York recently performed the first knee-replacement surgeries in the U.S. using augmented reality.

title: McConnell Proposes Starting Trump Impeachment Trial in Mid-February
summary: Former president picks Butch Bowers, a South Carolina attorney who previously served in the Justice Department, to represent him. WASHINGTON-Senate Minority Leader Mitch McConnell (R., Ky.) proposed starting former President Donald Trump's impeachment trial in mid-February, saying that time frame would give Democrats prosecuting the case and Mr. Trump's defense team time to prepare.

title: Mytheresa IPO Nets $2.2 Billion Value, Vindicating Neiman Marcus Holdout
summary: IPO brings to fruition fight spearheaded by Marble Ridge Capital founder Dan Kamensky. Mytheresa Group GmbH, the European luxury e-commerce platform and former Neiman Marcus Group Ltd. subsidiary, went public Wednesday at a $2.2 billion valuation, vindicating creditors who waged a two-year campaign to win back the asset after a 2018 spinoff placed it out of their reach.

title: Intel to Outsource More Production
summary: Incoming CEO says chip maker plans to outsource more production. Intel Corp.'s incoming Chief Executive Pat Gelsinger said the semiconductor giant would outsource more chip production, as it posted pandemic-fueled full-year results that also underscored the breadth of challenges the new CEO will face.

title: Biden's Agenda Faces Early Hurdles in a Divided Congress
summary: GOP senators refuse to strike power-sharing deal if Democrats don't commit to preserving filibuster; McConnell proposes Trump trial in two weeks. Democrats' efforts to quickly confirm President Biden's cabinet nominees and move forward with his legislative agenda collided with the reality of a narrowly divided Congress, with Senate Republicans refusing to agree to a power-sharing agreement unless Democrats promise to preserve a 60-vote threshold to advance most bills.

title: Intel to Stay Mostly Inside
summary: Chip maker hints at more outsourcing, but expects majority of future chips to be made in-house. Even Pat Gelsinger can only do so much in a week.

title: Florida to Require Vaccine Recipients to Show Proof of Residency
summary: Move comes after outcry over vaccine tourism, where people were visiting from abroad to get vaccinated. Florida's surgeon general issued a directive Thursday requiring people seeking Covid-19 vaccines to be permanent or seasonal residents of the state, amid concerns that foreign visitors were flying in to secure shots.

title: Brooklyn Handyman Accused of Three Separate Killings in Same Complex
summary: Kevin Gavin's alleged victims were elderly neighbors living in a NYCHA complex for seniors. Officers arrested a Brooklyn handyman for killing three elderly neighbors on separate occasions from 2015 to 2021 inside the same New York City Housing Authority apartment building, New York Police Department officials said Thursday.

title: All 12 Regional Fed Bank Heads Get New Terms
summary: Current seconds-in-command at regional banks also were approved for new terms, in a process described by Fed governor Lael Brainard as 'rigorous'. The Federal Reserve said Thursday that all 12 regional bank presidents and their current seconds-in-command are approved for new five-year terms.
